title: Who are the suspects in Sky Crime’s The Case Of Adnan Syed?
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Sky Crime documentary The Case Of Adnan Syed delves into Hae Min Lee’s brutal murder in Maryland in 1999.

Her ex-boyfriend Adnan Syed was arrested and charged with her death, with the prosecution arguing that he had strangled Lee after she had dumped him.

Syed, who maintains his innocence, was later found guilty of the murder, as well as robbery, kidnapping and false imprisonment and was sentenced to life in prison plus an extra 30 years.

Although the accused is serving time there are a number of theories about who could have carried out the crime. Let’s take a look at them.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Adnan Syed

The most obvious suspect is Adnan Syed himself.

Syed and Lee started dating at the beginning of 1998 but by December they had broken up and she was dating another man.

The 39-year-old has been behind bars since the age of 18 for Lee’s death and was looked into as a suspect three days after Lee’s body was found.

Lee disappeared on January 13, 1999 and her family reported her missing after she failed to pick up her younger cousin from daycare around 3.15pm.

She had gone to school that day and had been seen by a number of people leaving at the end of the day.

Jay Wilds said he heard Syed confess to the murder, but this information conflicts a fellow student’s claim that she saw him in the library at school on the afternoon of Lee’s disappearance.

Adnan Syed has been charged with Lee’s murder (Picture: HBO)

Jay Wilds and Adnan Syed

Jay Wilds was a key witness during the trial and his statement was crucial to prosecuting Syed.

Wilds had Syed’s phone on the day of Lee’s murder and he initially denied any knowledge of the crime.

After some time, Wilds told police that Syed had shown him Lee’s body in the carpark of a Best Buy and that they both buried the body in Leakin Park at around 7pm later that evening.

Jay Wilds was a friend of Syed’s (Picture: HBO)

During his interview, however, Wilds frequently seemed to lose his way which was marked by knocking and tapping sounds. After hearing these sounds, he seemed to remember what happened and insisted that Syed carried out the murder.

Advertisement

Advertisement

According to attorney Susan Simpson, the tapping was evidence that the police were feeding Wilds with elements of his supposed story.

In a statement shared in 2019, Wilds said that his statement regarding seeing the body at Best Buy came from the police.

Was Wilds more involved with the murder than he let on?

Alonzo Sellers found Hae Min Lee’s body

Alonzo Sellers

Alonzo Sellers found Lee’s body in Leakin Park as he made a toilet stop on February 9 1999.

Sellers told police he’d been drinking a 22-ounce Budweiser as he drove back to a school where he worked as a janitor, when he pulled over to use the bathroom.

Hae Min Lee was murdered in 1999

(Picture: Woodlawn High School)

‘I had to go to the bathroom so I pulled over and I went further in the woods so no one could see me,’ he said in the series.

‘I walked around through the bushes and everything and I got back that way and I was getting ready to urinate when I looked down I seen something that looked like hair, something was covered by the dirt.

‘And I looked real good again, and that’s when I seen what looked like a foot.’

Sellers reportedly had a criminal past, but could he have killed Lee?

Talking about whether Sellers found Lee’s body the way he said he did, Decetive Darryl Massey said in the documentary: ‘I’m not going to support that he didn’t – don’t think he wasn’t looked at.

Advertisement

‘I certainly understood some prior documented issues.’

Could Alonzo have murdered Lee?

Ronald Lee Moore

Ronald Lee Moore wasn’t a suspect in Lee’s murder until 2014 when The University of Virginia’s Innocence Project identified him.

Moore took his own life in prison

Moore was released from prison 10 day before Lee was killed and 11 months after her death, another Korean woman, Annelise Hyang Suk Lee, was killed.

It was uncovered through DNA evidence that he had murdered Suk Lee by blunt force trauma and strangulation.

‘In some ways, he was ideal because he had been released from prison and fit the timeframe for Hae’s murder because he had been out for 10 days when she was murdered,’ Deirdre Enright, head of the Innocence Project, told TIME.

Moore took his own life in prison in 2012 after being arrested for charges unrelated to either murder.

The Case of Adnan Syed is available to watch on Sky Crime.

description: Who are the suspects in Sky Crime's The Case Of Adnan Syed? Here's a list of suspects involved in Hae Min Lee's murder.
